text:
eds intravenous
labetalol to control her high blood pressure- by this time she should preferably already be at specialist level of
care, as labetalol is not available at primary care.
• This should preferably take place within a high care setting with invasive blood pressure monitoring:
o Labetalol, IV infusion, 2 mg/minute to a total of 1–2 mg/kg.
o Reconstitute solution as follows:
 Discard 40 mL of sodium chloride 0.9% from a 200 mL container.
 Add 2 vials (2 x 100 mg) of labetalol (5 mg/mL
